engine.title: BASIC PROGRAM FOR WELDING OPERATION
engine.description:
This course is designed to enhance or broaden the knowledge and skill of engine personnel, particularly engineers in common welding practices available on board.

Participants in this course will undergo hands-on training that enhances their knowledge and skill in welding operation and how to assess the quality of weld in accordance with industry standards.  It covers competency such as Weld Carbon steel Plates using various welding processes such as Shielded Metal Arc Welding (SMAW), Oxygen-acetylene Welding (OAW), Tungsten Inert Gas (TIG), and Metal Inert Gas (MIG) welding processes, which they can actually perform for them to experience the real pace of operation.  The kinds of electrodes, properties of metal to be welded, heat treatment, hard facing and rebuilding of metals will be taken in Basic Welding Metallurgy. The use and characteristics of different kinds of electrodes are also discussed in the course.  The application safety practices, use of hand tools, prepare weld materials, setup welding equipment, fit-up weld materials, repair welds, brazing and oxyacetylene cutting are also included.	
The modules enumerated below shall be given appropriate time allocation both for theoretical preparation and for practical application of the competencies.

SAFETY IN GAS AND ELECTRIC WELDING: Common Hazards in Electric and Gas Welding or Cutting
Protective equipment used in Welding and Cutting
Safe Handling and Storing of Gas Cylinders

BASIC METALLURGY: Heat Treatment, Hard Facing and Rebuilding of Metal

GAS TUNGSTEN ARC WELDING (GTAW/TIG): Benefits of GTAW or TIG Welding

OXYACETYLENE WELDING AND CUTTING OPERATI: Actual Welding, Cutting and Brazing Operation

ASSESSING QUALITY WORKS IN WELDING: The effect of current, arc length and travel speed on covered electrode beads

deck.title: BASIC RIGGING AND SLINGING
deck.description:
The course will give informative practices on basic rigging and slinging operation, such as, the Principle Rigging and the common terminologies commonly encountered in rigging, Safe Working System for Rigging and Lifting, Types of Ropes, Sling and Lifting Equipment, Rigging and Slinging Risk Assessment, Communication used in rigging and the Operation of Crane and its Maintenance. 

For as much as detailed description of what is to be taken for the entire days of training, the modules will be discussed and tackled as followed:

SAFE WORKING SYSTEM FOR RIGGING AND LIFT: Breaking Stress of Ropes and Sling
Safe Positioning of Personnel when Lifting

TYPES OF ROPES, SLINGS AND LIFTING EQUIP: Short splice, long splice and eye splice.
Tools used in splicing: clamps. cutters, spikes, vise, bench, etc.

RIGGING AND SLINGING RISK ASSESSMENT: Slips and Falls (Common Fatal on Board).

GAS TUNGSTEN ARC WELDING (GTAW/TIG): Benefits of GTAW or TIG Welding

OXYACETYLENE WELDING AND CUTTING OPERATI: Actual Welding, Cutting and Brazing Operation

ASSESSING QUALITY WORKS IN WELDING: The effect of current, arc length and travel speed on covered electrode beads
